titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Chard Powers Smith Papers
titlestmt.author: by Andrea Benefiel and Ellen Doon

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:24

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers contain writings, correspondence, personal papers, photographs, and family papers of twentieth-century American writer Chard Powers Smith. The collection documents his career through drafts of his writings and through correspondence that reveals his personal and professional relationships with fellow writers, publishers, and literary organizations. The papers also contain information about his family, documenting not only his relationships with family members but also the lives of his parents and grandparents in nineteenth-century Watertown, New York. Smith's experiences during World War I and his travels in Europe in the 1920s are documented through correspondence, autobiographical writings, photographs, and scrapbooks. His involvement with the Distributist and Agrarian movements of the 1930s is evidenced by correspondence, writings, and printed ephemera, and the collection also documents his involvement with the Society of Friends, or Quakers, particularly from the 1950s through the end of his life.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Chard Powers Smith and Eunice Clark Smith, 1950-1989.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Cold Storage (Photographic negatives): Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Chard Powers Smith Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Chard Powers Smith Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The bulk of this collection was arranged and rehoused by the library in the 1960s and 1970s, and this arrangement was for the most part preserved during final processing in 2008. Changes to the arrangement included moving correspondence by Smith's family members to each other from the Correspondence series into the Family Papers series, and integrating previously restricted material into the collection.
Material in this collection formerly had the call numbers ZA Smith, C.P.; Uncat.ZA File.188; and Uncat.ZA MS.116.

bioghist.head: Chard Powers Smith (1894-1977)
bioghist.p: The writer Chard Powers Smith was born in Watertown, New York, and educated at the Pawling School and Yale University, class of 1916. Following service as a captain in the U.S. Army Field Artillery during World War I, he received a law degree from Harvard in 1921, but early abandoned the practice of law to make his living as a writer. A regular at the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, New Hampshire, throughout his career, he published in a variety of genres. His best known works include Artillery of Time , a historical novel; Where the Light Falls , a biography/memoir of the poet Edwin Arlington Robinson; and The Housatonic: Puritan River , part of the Rivers of America series.

Smith was born into comfortable circumstances in upstate New York, his parents' marriage having joined two of Watertown's most prominent families. His father, Edward North Smith, practiced law in partnership with his father, and was later a Justice of the New York Supreme Court, Fifth District. His mother, Alice Lamon Powers, the daughter of a wealthy businessman, died in childbirth when Smith was eleven. Smith maintained a home in an old mill in nearby Sackets Harbor for many years, and based much of his writing on family and local history.

Like many writers of his generation, Smith traveled and lived in Europe intermittently in the 1920s, and moved in American expatriate social and literary circles. He studied at Oxford in 1921, and in that year also married Olive Cary Macdonald; she died of complications from pregnancy in 1924 while the two were living in Italy. In addition to inspiring his own volume of poetry, Along the Wind , Smith's first marriage was purported to be a source for Ernest Hemingway's short story "Mr. and Mrs. Elliot;" Smith maintained a bitter grudge about the story all his life.

In 1929 Smith married Marion Antoinette ("Nanette") Chester. The couple lived in Connecticut and had two children, Chard Powers Smith, Jr., and Marion Kendall Smith. Smith and his second wife divorced in 1957, and in the same year he married Eunice Waters Clark, a professor of French. After spending the last two decades of his life in Arlington, Vermont, Smith died in a nursing home in Williamstown, Massachusetts, in 1977.

Sources of information include: Monroe, Joel H. Through Eleven Decades of History: Watertown, a History from 1800 to 1912 with Illustrations and Many Incidents (Watertown: Hungerford-Holbrook Co., 1912), and Haddock, John A. The Growth of a Century: as Illustrated in the History of Jefferson County, New York, from 1793-1894 (Philadelphia: Sherman & Co., 1894).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers contain writings, correspondence, personal papers, photographs, and family papers of twentieth-century American writer Chard Powers Smith, who wrote in several genres including poetry, historical fiction, and literary analysis. The collection documents his career through drafts of his writings and through correspondence that reveals his personal and professional relationships with fellow writers, publishers, and literary organizations. The papers also contain information about his family, documenting not only his relationships with family members but also the lives of his parents and grandparents in nineteenth-century Watertown, New York. Smith's experiences during World War I and his travels in Europe in the 1920s are documented through correspondence, autobiographical writings, photographs, and scrapbooks. His involvement in the Distributist and Agrarian movements of the 1930s is evidenced by correspondence, writings, and printed ephemera, and the collection also documents his involvement with the Society of Friends, or Quakers, particularly from the 1950s through the end of his life.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Correspondence (1901-1978). II. Writings (circa 1922-1956, undated). III. Personal Papers (1759-1977). IV. Family Papers (1852-1965, undated). V. Subject Files and Printed Material (circa 1920s-1960s). VI. Photographs (circa 1870s-1960s).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I. Correspondence is organized into four subseries: General Correspondence, Family Correspondence, Third Party Correspondence and Correspondence Photocopies. Each subseries is arranged alphabetically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General Correspondence contains Chard Powers Smith's correspondence spanning 1910-1978. Carbon copies and drafts of outgoing letters are interfiled with incoming correspondence, and in some cases files contain only outgoing letters. Smith's correspondence documents his personal and professional relationships throughout his life. Of interest among his literary correspondence is a file of acrimonious letters to and from Hemingway concerning Smith's reaction to the story "Mr. and Mrs. Elliot"; this matter is further documented in correspondence with the biographer Carlos Baker, who obtained Smith's copies of the letters. Some of the larger files in the subseries include professional exchanges with editors and publishers, and personal correspondence with friends such as James Rorty, Mark Van Doren, Bernardine Szold, and Rose Gollup Cohen. Also present is a substantial file documenting Smith's involvement, along with Ralph Borsodi and others, in an effort to unite the Distributist and Agrarian movements, and his his co-editorship of the periodical Free America ; this correspondence is filed together under the heading Distributist-Agrarian Movement. An extensive file concerning the Friends Seminary in New York City also documents Smith's involvement with the Albany Friends Meeting.

The Family Correspondence subseries contains correspondence between Chard Powers Smith and members of his family, spanning the years 1901 to 1977. The files of letters home to his parents and grandmother are extensive and give details about his experiences at the Pawling School, at Yale, in World War I, and in Europe after the war, while other letters document his relationships with his wives, children, grandchildren, and extended family. Additional family correspondence can be found in Series IV. Family Papers.

Third Party Correspondence contains letters to and from other parties, spanning the years 1919-1973. Correspondence Photocopies duplicates a small portion of the general correspondence, and may be related to Smith's work on his autobiography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. Writings contains notes, outlines, drafts, and proofs documenting Smith's writing career from his first volume of poetry, Along the Wind , published by Yale University Press in 1925, through an extensive autobiography that he worked on towards the end of his life. Most drafts are heavily annotated, and some are accompanied by research materials and reviews. Other research material can be found in Series I. Correspondence, and in Series V. Subject Files and Printed Material. Contracts and royalty statements can be found in Series III. Personal Papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into four subseries: Prose, Poetry, Drama, and Writings of Others. Each subseries, excluding Writings of Others, is arranged alphabetically by title of the work, or by format for shorter works. The Writings of Others subseries is further divided by genre, and the writings are listed alphabetically by author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. Personal Papers contains address books, diaries, journals, financial and legal papers, school notebooks and other material pertaining to the personal life of Chard Powers Smith. Also present are scrapbooks documenting significant aspects of Smith's life and writing career in the 1920s; these contain reviews and other clippings, a few photographs, and correspondence including notes from John Masefield, Marianne Moore, Harriet Monroe, and other writers, as well as the attending doctor's account of Olive Smith's death. Of note among the legal papers is a 1759 deed documenting the sale of land in Dunstable, Province of New Hampshire, by Jonathan Powers to Isaac Powers.

did.unittitle: Financial statements, account books, invoices and receipts

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes one deed of land, dated 1759, signed by Jonathan Powers.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook pages related to undergraduate activities at Yale

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by family member. Correspondence by family members is listed separately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV. Family Papers contains personal papers of Chard Powers Smith's family members. These include diaries and journals, other writings, financial papers, school notebooks and other personal papers of his mother, father, maternal grandmother, and his first wife. The series also includes correspondence of a broader circle of Smith's family members, with the exception of their correspondence with Smith, which is located in Series I. Material in this series chiefly documents the family's daily life in and near Watertown, New York in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century, although a substantial file of letters from Edward North Smith to his father concerns his experiences at Hamilton College in the 1880s.

did.unittitle: Micklejohn, Helen to Clark, Paul and Alice

Young, Mary Louisa to Powers Household

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains printed ephemera, pamphlets, and clippings collected by Smith to document his work, as background research for writing projects, and for personal interest. The clippings include reviews of his work and his own letters to editors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI. Photographs includes portraits and snapshots of Smith throughout his life, as well as images of his family members and a few of friends and schoolmates. Images of his parents and grandparents include portraits and school photographs from the late nineteenth century. A few World War I images are present, showing soldiers and Olive Macdonald as a nurse, as are some images of Smith in Europe in the 1920s with friends including Bernardine Szold and Monroe Wheeler. The series also includes an album of photographs of the mill at Sackets Harbor, New York, by Prentiss Taylor, with related correspondence. Images related to Smith's writings, including reproduction photographs of Edwin Arlington Robinson, are also present. A few additional photographs can be found in the scrapbooks in Series III. Personal Papers.
